snippet: Self-imposed bans carry several advantages for universities, like displaying cooperation, but they can keep an innocent player out of the postseason.
abstract: Marc Tracy On College Basketball column says that self-imposed bans, like one Syracuse imposed on men's basketball program for staff members doing homework for players as well as other indiscretions, hurt specific athletes, instead of program as whole; notes that Syracuse is competing in 2016 NCAA tournament, but forced senior star Rakeem Christmas to miss his final tournament because of self-imposed ban last season.
lead_paragraph: Self-imposed bans carry several advantages for universities, like displaying cooperation, but they can keep an innocent player out of the postseason.

headline.main: Syracuse Was Aided by Self-Imposed Ban, but a Player Paid a Price
headline.print_headline: Self-Imposed Ban Can Aid a University but Hurt the Innocent
